name: light olefins production, from methanol-to-olefins conversion, ethylene-to-propylene ratio of 0.67 | pentane | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/30576/documentation

This dataset represents the combined production of light olefins via the catalytic dehydration of methanol. Namely, this dataset covers the production of 1.00 kg of propylene and 0.67 kg of ethylene as reference products. At the same time, the formed liquefied petroleum gas, pentane, and gasoline (0.03, 0.04, and 0.06 kg, respectively) are treated as valuable by-products. The process includes, feedstock, materials, energy and registers all relevant direct emissions.;Light olefins are crucial building blocks for the chemicals and plastics sector and are predominantly generated through steam cracking of hydrocarbons. The annual production volume of ethylene and propylene are extremely high and constitutes them as the most highly produced petrochemicals. The high production volume of light olefins is driven by a high demand, which in 2007 amounted to 115 and 73 Mt for ethylene and propylene, respectively.;Notably, methanol may be used to cover part of the ethylene and propylene demand. Besides, such pathway may be appealing to decouple the production of light olefins from the petroleum feedstocks, e.g., naphtha.;The share of the produced light olefins, through the methanol-to-olefins (MTO) process, depends on the operating conditions of the reactor and the used catalyst. The latter process variables are able to modify the weight ratio of propylene-to-ethylene, to either maximize the yield towards ethylene or propylene (i.e., amount of ethylene < propylene, or vice versa). Furthermore, the upgrade of C4-C5 fractions is also considered, enhancing the yield towards propylene.;In the present dataset, there are two reference products (ethylene and propylene), thus allocation (subdivision) of the Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) is required. The allocation is based on mass content. For more information, consult the ''Modelling & Administrative'' section.;References:;Olah, G.A. (2005), Beyond Oil and Gas: The Methanol Economy. Angewandte Chemie International Edition, 44: 2636-2639. https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.200462121;Yang, M., Fan, D., Wei, Y., Tian, P., Liu, Z., Recent Progress in Methanol-to-Olefins (MTO) Catalysts. Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1902181. https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201902181;Bertau, M., Offermanns, H., Plass, L., Schmidt, F., & Wernicke, H. J. (Eds.). (2014). Methanol: the basic chemical and energy feedstock of the future (Vol. 1). Heidelberg: Springer.

The activity starts with the raw materials entering the methano-to-olefins facility.

The activity ends with the final products being ready for further processing or transportation at the production site gate. The dataset includes the consumption of raw materials and energy, estimated catalyst use, emissions to air and water from the process, as well as the infrastructure use.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This activity originates from literature data, for conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO) published in 2021. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and not expected to change significantly over the next 5 years.;References:;Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This inventory is modelled for China, where the coal-to- and methanol-to-olefins technologies are important technological pathways to produce light olefins.;According to Lv et al (2021), in 2019, 24% of propylene produced in China was supplied from methanol conversion plants. Furthermore, based on Wood Mackenzie, in 2019, the installed capacity of ethylene from CTO/MTO accounted for 21% of China’s total ethylene capacity.;This activity originates from literature data for the conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO) for China. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and are, therefore, considered to be valid for the chosen geography.;References:;2021, Lin Lv, Guobao Song, Xinyue Zhao, Jingwen Chen, Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799;https://www.woodmac.com/news/can-chinas-cto-and-mto-industries-survive-the-threat-of-massive-steam-cracker-investment/, assessed in 2023-10-09.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In this dataset, the catalytic conversion of methanol to light olefins originates from  the work by Lv et al. (2021) that was, in turn, based on the environmental impact assessment report for a joint venture between China Power Investment Corporation and Total, Ltd., in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China.;In the methanol-to-olefins process, the methanol feedstock is first dehydrated to dimethyl ether (DME), and DME, in turn, dehydrates further to yield ethylene, propylene, and smaller amounts of butenes. Hence, the conversion of methanol into olefins covers the following reaction steps:;1) Dehydration of methanol to DME: ;2 CH3OH <--> CH3OCH3 + H2O;2) Production of light olefins through DME dehydration:;CH3OCH3 --> C2H4 + H2O;CH3OCH3 --> 2/3 C3H6 + H2O;CH3OCH3 --> 2/4 C4H8 + H2O;Other reactions take place simultaneously, which give yield to methane, ethane, C5 hydrocarbons, hydrogen, coke, and CO2. At the same time, additional steps to upgrade the C4-C5 fractions could enhance the yield towards propylene.;This inventory covers the production of propylene, ethylene, LPG, C5s, and gasoline, along with the consumption of energy and auxiliary materials and services. The data is based on an existing project for the coal-to-olefins production process. Namely, the plant, which this inventory represents, is located in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China and was built in 2016. This plant has an annual olefin output of 800 000 t,;References:;2021, Lin Lv, Guobao Song, Xinyue Zhao, Jingwen Chen, Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799;Bertau, M., Offermanns, H., Plass, L., Schmidt, F., & Wernicke, H. J. (Eds.). (2014). Methanol: the basic chemical and energy feedstock of the future (Vol. 1). Heidelberg: Springer.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data obtained from the literature. 
References:
2021, Lin Lv, Guobao Song, Xinyue Zhao, Jingwen Chen, Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799

Due to the fact that that there are two  reference products in this dataset, subdivision of the exchange amounts between ethylene and propylene is required first. This subdivision is based on the shares of mass from the respective products. The ethylene contribution is 0.67 kg while propylene contribute roughly 1.0  kg. The resulting fractions for the subdivision are approximately 40.12 and 59.88% for ethylene, propylene, and butenes, respectively. Meaning that 40.12% of the exchanges are allocated to ethylene production and the remaining 59.88% are allocated to propylene production.

exchanges.description: Value reported by Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

flow.name: pentane
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description: The original source did not provide information on the consumption of cooling water. This elementary exchange is added for completion based on a similar process. Namely, the methanol-to-olefins conversion, with an ethylene-to-propylene ratio of 1.51 (instead of 0.67 of this dataset), available in the ecoinvent Database v.3.10.

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

exchanges.description:
Main raw material for the production of light olefins. According to the operating rates of methanol-to- and coal-to-olefins plants in China, 60% of capacity is covered by coal-based methanol, according to https://infogram.com/methanol_asia_ctotable_october22-1ho16vod7o5yx4n, accessed 15-09-2023. The remaining 40% is covered by the methanol market.

Reference:
 Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.
